name: methyl_propyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-propanedisulfide has a melting point of around -100°C due to the presence of a rigid structure with a sulfur atom at the center, which increases molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. The methyl group introduces a small increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +5°C. The propyl group introduces a rigid structure with increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around +20°C. The sulfur atom introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C.
